elements.content: Seven complexes based on the ligands 4,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (4-HOBPT) and 4,6-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (3-HOBPT), namely, [Fe(4-OBPT)2(H2O)2]·6H2O (2), M(4-OBPT)(INA)(H2O) (M = Co(II) (3a), Fe(II) (3b), Zn(II) (3c), HINA = isonicotinic acid), [Co(3-OBPT)2(H2O)2]·H2O (4), and [M(3-OBPT)(NA)(H2O)]·0.5CH3OH (M = Co(II) (5a), Ni(II) (5b), HNA = nicotinic acid), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The thermal stability and coordination model of the ligands are extremely dependent on the reaction temperature and the presence of metal ions. In the range of 90−120 °C, unique complexes 2 and 4 were obtained and the ligands are a N,O-bimonodentate coordination model. At 130 °C, complexes 3 and 5 were afforded in yields of 12−48% depending on the metal ions, in which both of the ligands act as a N,N,O-trimonodentate triangular ligand and the INA and NA anions are generated in situ by hydrolysis of the corresponding parents. The hydrolysis reaction is significantly promoted by Cu(II) ion even at a relative low temperature. Both 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands have different geometries and exhibit ligand-directed supramolecular assembly. In 4-OBPT, the coordination sites locate at the vertexes of the triangular pane; it connects two or three metal ions generating a (4,4) or (6,3) two-dimensional (2D) sheet. Differently, the 3-OBPT ligand chooses to form a M2L2 metallamacrocycle as a building unit generating a one-dimensional chain via sharing the metal ions or a (4,4) 2D net due to the coordination nitrogen atoms positioned on the edges of the triangular pane.

elements.content: The thermal stability and coordination model of ligands 4,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (4-HOBPT) and 4,6-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (3-HOBPT) are extremely dependent on the reaction temperature and the presence of metal ions under hydrothermal conditions. The great diversity in coordination sites of ligands 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT leads to various supramolecular self-assemblies.

elements.content: The assembly of metallo-supramolecular complexes based on polypyridyl ligands has been well documented. In particular, the rigid multidentate polypyridyl ligands containing a triazine ring as a bridge have attracted our attention greatly due to their coordination diversity. Among them, most of the attention has been paid to the symmetric tri(pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TPT) ligands, in which the different placement of the N-atom in the pyridyl group shows great diversity in coordination with metal ion and exhibits ligand-directed self-assembly. For example, tri(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (2-TPT) is apt to act as a tridentate ligand and form mononuclear complexes. However, both tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (4-TPT) and tri(3-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (3-TPT) ligands like to bind to metal ions in a trimonodentate model as a panel triangular ligand. The most significant cases are the assembly of nanosized, discrete Pd6L4 cations by Fujita’s group. A quantitative octahedral cage was produced when the 4-TPT ligand reacted with Pd(en)2(NO3)2. In marked difference, a bowl-like square-pyramidal cone was isolated in the change of the ligand from 4-TPT to 3-TPT. The different outcomes may be attributed to the ligand-directed assembly as shown in Scheme . As is known, the self-assembly of the supramolecular structure is highly mediated by the ligand geometry. Therefore, selecting a proper ligand with certain features, such as rigidity, appropriate angles, and versatile binding modes, to coordinate to the metal ion is crucial to the construction of supramolecules. This also provides a strategy for the design and synthesis of functional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The assembly of metallo-supramolecular complexes based on polypyridyl ligands has been well documented. In particular, the rigid multidentate polypyridyl ligands containing a triazine ring as a bridge have attracted our attention greatly due to their coordination diversity. Among them, most of the attention has been paid to the symmetric tri(pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TPT) ligands, in which the different placement of the N-atom in the pyridyl group shows great diversity in coordination with metal ion and exhibits ligand-directed self-assembly. For example, tri(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (2-TPT) is apt to act as a tridentate ligand and form mononuclear complexes. However, both tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (4-TPT) and tri(3-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (3-TPT) ligands like to bind to metal ions in a trimonodentate model as a panel triangular ligand. The most significant cases are the assembly of nanosized, discrete Pd6L4 cations by Fujita's group. A quantitative octahedral cage was produced when the 4-TPT ligand reacted with Pd(en)2(NO3)2. In marked difference, a bowl-like square-pyramidal cone was isolated in the change of the ligand from 4-TPT to 3-TPT. The different outcomes may be attributed to the ligand-directed assembly as shown in Scheme . As is known, the self-assembly of the supramolecular structure is highly mediated by the ligand geometry. Therefore, selecting a proper ligand with certain features, such as rigidity, appropriate angles, and versatile binding modes, to coordinate to the metal ion is crucial to the construction of supramolecules. This also provides a strategy for the design and synthesis of functional materials.

elements.content: Although the coordination chemistry of symmetrical ligands such as TPT has been well explored, observations of asymmetric ligands containing a triazine ring are still rare. With these considerations in mind, recently, we have designed and synthesized a family of rigid, asymmetric multidentate ligands on the basis of replacement of a pyridyl group from the TPT parent by a hydroxyl, namely, 4,6-bis(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (2-HOBPT), 4,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (4-HOBPT), and 4,6-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazin-2-ol (3-HOBPT) (see Scheme ). The primary studies show that the 2-HOBPT ligand has various coordination modes, such as tridentate terpyridine-like, bidentate bipyridine-like, and tetradentate bis-bipyridine-like. Using this ligand, we successfully assembled a hydrophobic, cubic, nanosize cation [Co(H2O)6⊂Co8(2-OBPT)12]6+ using [Co(H2O)6]2+ ion as a template, in which the 2-OBPT ligand adopts a rare, bis-bipyridine-like binding mode with the capability of bridging two cobalt(II) ions in a chelating manner. Furthermore, the deprotonated OH group accepts hydrogen bonding from the [Co(H2O)6]2+ ion that embeds in the central cavity as a guest and plays an indispensable role in the cage structure formation. When we extend the insight into the ligand 4-HOBPT, two isostructural complexes [M(4-OBPT)2]·0.6H2O (1, M = Co(II) and Ni(II)) were isolated, in which each ligand bridges two metal ions resulting in a (4,4) two-dimensional (2D) framework with rhombic cavities. In the meantime, we found that the triazine derivatives have a tendency of hydrolysis at high temperature and greatly depend on metal ions. As part of an ongoing study, we extend the observation of the analogous ligand 3-HOBPT that has a different geometry and the reaction at higher temperature. We hope that the 3-HOBPT ligand could possibly generate new architectures that would exploit the new motifs of this kind of ligand. In this contribution, the syntheses and structural characterization of two coordination polymers based on 4-HOBPT and 3-HOBPT ligands, namely, [Fe(4-OBPT)2(H2O)2]·6H2O (2) and [Co(3-OBPT)2(H2O)2]·H2O (4), have been reported. Moreover, structural characterization of complexes M(4-OBPT)(INA)(H2O) (M = Co(3a), Fe(3b), Zn(3c), HINA = isonicotinic acid) and [M(3-OBPT)(NA)(H2O)]·0.5CH3OH (M = Co(5a), Ni(5b), HNA = nicotinic acid) obtained at higher temperature has also been reported, in which INA and NA ligands were generated in situ by hydrolysis of 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands, respectively, under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of metal ions.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Vario EL elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian 300 MHz spectrometer at 25 °C. Electron spray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were obtained on a LCQ DECA XP quadrupole ion trap mass spectrometer with methanol as the carrier solvent. Thermogravimetric data were collected on a Netzsch TGS-2 analyzer in nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5409 Å) at a scanning rate of 4° min−1 with 2θ ranging from 5° to 40°.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Vario EL elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian 300 MHz spectrometer at 25 °C. Electron spray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were obtained on a LCQ DECA XP quadrupole ion trap mass spectrometer with methanol as the carrier solvent. Thermogravimetric data were collected on a Netzsch TGS-2 analyzer in nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5409 Å) at a scanning rate of 4° min-1 with 2θ ranging from 5° to 40°.

elements.content: They were prepared according to previously reported procedures, using of 4-cyanopyridine or 3-cyanopyridine instead of 2-cyanopyridine as the starting material. For 4-HOBPT: Yield 72% based on urea. ESI-MS: m/z = 250 [M − H]−. 1H NMR data (DMSO-d 6, ppm): 8.815 (d, J = 1.84 Hz, 4H), 8.27 (d, J = 1.80 Hz, 4H). For 3-HOBPT: Yield 60% based on urea. ESI-MS: m/z = 250 [M − H]−. 1H NMR data (DMSO-d 6, ppm): 9.50 (s, 2H), 8.77 (d, J = 4.75 Hz, 2H), 8.69 (d, J = 7.95 Hz, 2H), 7.58(t, 2H).

Syntheses of 4-HOBPT and 3-HOBPT

They were prepared according to previously reported procedures, using of 4-cyanopyridine or 3-cyanopyridine instead of 2-cyanopyridine as the starting material. For 4-HOBPT: Yield 72% based on urea. ESI-MS: m/z = 250 [M - H]-. 1H NMR data (DMSO-d 6, ppm): 8.815 (d, J = 1.84 Hz, 4H), 8.27 (d, J = 1.80 Hz, 4H). For 3-HOBPT: Yield 60% based on urea. ESI-MS: m/z = 250 [M - H]-. 1H NMR data (DMSO-d 6, ppm): 9.50 (s, 2H), 8.77 (d, J = 4.75 Hz, 2H), 8.69 (d, J = 7.95 Hz, 2H), 7.58(t, 2H).

elements.content: 4-HOBPT (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol), 7 mL of distilled water, and 7 mL of methanol were put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr vessel. The mixture was heated at 90−130 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1. The resulting mixture was filtered. The crystals were washed by water, dried at room temperature, and collected by manual separation under a microscope. At 90−120 °C, unique yellow 1a was obtained in about 90% yield on the basis of 4-HOBPT. When the temperature was increased to 130 °C, mixed complexes 1a and 3a were obtained. Yield of 3a: 12% based on 4-HOBPT. Anal. Calcd for C19H14CoN6O4 (3a): C, 50.79, H, 3.14, N, 18.71%. Found: C, 50.87, H, 3.32, N, 18.54%. FT IR (KBr, cm−1): 3553 (m), 3435 (s), 3246 (m), 3115 (w), 1630 (vs), 1572 (vs), 1524 (s), 1468 (s), 1373 (vs), 1223 (m), 1144 (w), 1061 (m), 1014 (m), 824 (m), 771 (m), 698 (m), 552 (w), 507 (m).

elements.content: 4-HOBPT (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol), FeCl2·6H2O (0.118 g, 0.5 mmol), 7 mL of distilled water, and 7 mL of methanol were put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr vessel. The mixture was heated at 100−130 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1, and the resulting mixture was filtered. The crystals were dried at room temperature and collected by manual separation under a microscope. At 100 °C, only red 2 was obtained in 60% based on 4-HOBPT. Anal. Calcd for C26H32FeN10O10 (2): C, 44.58, H, 4.60, N, 19.99%. Found: C, 45.22, H, 4.32, N, 20.44%. FT IR (KBr, cm−1): 3404 (s), 3242 (w), 1641 (m), 1580 (m), 1518 (vs), 1481 (vs), 1373 (s), 1315 (w), 1271 (w), 1217 (w), 1188 (w), 1142 (w), 1061 (m), 1011 (m), 854 (w), 820 (s), 758 (w), 698 (m), 650 (m), 505 (m). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment of 2 was carried out from 30 to 750 °C. The weight loss of 20.2% in the range of 20−200 °C (see Figure S6 in the ) corresponds to the loss of eight water molecules (six lattice and two coordinated water molecules, calculated 20.5%). When the temperature was set to 130 °C, two compounds 2 (red, 50%) and 3b (black, 18%) were obtained. Anal. Calcd for C19H14FeN6O4 (3b): C, 51.14, H, 3.16, N, 18.83%; Found: C, 51.02, H, 3.42, N, 18.27%. FT IR (KBr, cm−1): 3448 (s), 2926 (w), 1630 (vs), 1582 (vs), 1523 (s), 1475 (vs), 1375 (vs), 1221 (m), 1142 (w), 1061 (m), 1016 (m), 947 (w), 862(w), 822 (s), 765 (m), 698 (s), 507 (w).

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for the complexes were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs, respectively. Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (C−H 0.96 Å and N−H 0.86 Å). The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinement for the complexes, are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table .

Symmetry code for 2: A, −x, −y + 2, −z; B, x, −y + 3/2, z − 1/2; 3a, A, x, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2; B, x, −y + 3/2, z + 1/2; C, x − 1, y, z; 3b, A, x, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2; B, x, −y + 3/2, z + 1/2; C, x − 1, y, z; 3c, A, x, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2; B, x, −y + 3/2, z + 1/2; C, x − 1, y, z; 4, A: x, −y, z + 1/2; B: −x + 1, −y, −z + 1; C: −x + 1, y, −z + 3/2. 5a: A: −x + 2, −y, −z + 1; B: x − 1/2, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2. 5b: A: −x + 2, −y, −z + 1; B: x − 1/2, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic P21/c space group. As shown in Figure a, Fe(II) ion locates on a symmetry inversion center and is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two deprotonated ligands (Fe1−O1 = 2.084(1) Å), two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from another two ligands (Fe1−N1 = 2.210(2) Å), and two water molecules (Fe1−O1W = 2.150(1) Å) to furnish an octahedral geometry. Similar to the complexes [M(4-OBPT)2]·0.6H2O (1), only a moiety of pyridyl group coordinates to the metal ion and the residual half is “free” and further accepts a hydrogen bond from the water molecule. Each ligand bridges two Fe(II) ions and each metal ion links to four ligands, resulting in a (4,4) 2D framework with rhombic cavities, as shown in Figure b. The M···M distances across the 4-OBPT ligands and through the diagonals are 10.76, 12.74, and 17.34 Å, respectively. Two uncoordinated pyridine rings fill in a rhombic cavity and further stack by strong π−π interactions between the triazine ring and uncoordinated pyridine ring with a distance of 3.36 Å. Differently, the ligand 4-OBPT is a tridentate in 1, adopting an unusual N,O-exo-bidentate chelating and N-monodentate mode. Here, the 4-OBPT ligand is a N,O-bimonodentate through a pyridyl nitrogen atom and hydroxyl; the nitrogen atoms in the triazine ring do not bind to metal ion.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 2 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic P21/c space group. As shown in Figure a, Fe(II) ion locates on a symmetry inversion center and is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two deprotonated ligands (Fe1-O1 = 2.084(1) Å), two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from another two ligands (Fe1-N1 = 2.210(2) Å), and two water molecules (Fe1-O1W = 2.150(1) Å) to furnish an octahedral geometry. Similar to the complexes [M(4-OBPT)2]⋅0.6H2O (1), only a moiety of pyridyl group coordinates to the metal ion and the residual half is "free" and further accepts a hydrogen bond from the water molecule. Each ligand bridges two Fe(II) ions and each metal ion links to four ligands, resulting in a (4,4) 2D framework with rhombic cavities, as shown in Figure b. The M⋅⋅⋅M distances across the 4-OBPT ligands and through the diagonals are 10.76, 12.74, and 17.34 Å, respectively. Two uncoordinated pyridine rings fill in a rhombic cavity and further stack by strong π-π interactions between the triazine ring and uncoordinated pyridine ring with a distance of 3.36 Å. Differently, the ligand 4-OBPT is a tridentate in 1, adopting an unusual N,O-exo-bidentate chelating and N-monodentate mode. Here, the 4-OBPT ligand is a N,O-bimonodentate through a pyridyl nitrogen atom and hydroxyl; the nitrogen atoms in the triazine ring do not bind to metal ion.

elements.content: Moreover, two coordinated water molecules are vertically positioned up and down the layer that further links each other via lattice water molecules into a three-dimensional (3D) hydrogen-bonded network (see Figure a). The interlayer distances are 6.79 Å. The most interesting observation is the water layers positioned between the coordination layers. As shown in Figure b, two coordinated O1W and four lattice water molecules (two O2W and two O4W) link each other by hydrogen bonding (O1W···O2W = 2.820 Å, O1W···O4W = 2.771 Å, O4W···O2W = 2.855 Å) to form a chair conformation cyclic water hexamer. The hydrogen-bonding parameters are comparable to the previous report. The cyclic water clusters further connect to each other by O3W molecules (O2W···O3W = 2.79 Å, O4W···O3W = 3.19 Å) into a 2D hydrogen-bonded net, as shown in Figure b. The water layers are stabilized between the coordination layers via hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: When the reaction temperature was increased to 130 °C in the presence of Co(II), Fe(II), and Zn(II), we found that part 4-OBPT ligands hydrolyzed to INA and the mixed ligands complexes 3a, 3b, and 3c were afforded in situ, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that they are isostructural structures with a monoclinic P21/c space group. As shown in Figure a, each metal ion is coordinated by one hydroxyl oxygen atom (M−O = 2.075(2), 2.010(1), and 2.132(2) Å) and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (M−N = 2.182(3)−2.317(2) Å) from three 4-OBPT ligands, one pyridyl N atom (M−N = 2.165(3), 2.193(2), and 2.168(2) Å) and one carboxyl O atom (M−O = 2.030(2), 1.961(2), and 2.027(2) Å) from two INA− and one water molecule (M−OW =2.167(2), 2.304(2), and 2.181(2) Å) to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry. Each 4-OBPT ligand coordinates to three metal ions acting as a N,N,O-trimonodentate triangular ligand which has a similar coordination model with 4-TPT, but different from those coordination models adopted in complexes 1 and 2. Here, every metal ion coordinates to three 4-OBPT ligands and every ligand connects to three metal ions to yield a (6,3) 2D wavelike layer on the ac plane, as shown in Figure b,c. These are different from the (4,4) nets in complexes 1 and 2 (vide supra). Each INA ligand in situ generated from the hydrolysis of 4-OBPT ligand coordinates to two metal ions via the pyridyl N6, and one of the carboxyl oxygen atoms O2 acts as a pillar that connects the 2D wavelike sheets into a pillared-layer 3D framework (see Figure d). Furthermore, the coordinated water molecule O1W donates an intramolecular hydrogen bond to the N4 (O1W···N4 = 2.874(2), 2.794(2), and 2.856(2) Å) from the triazine ring and further hydrogen bonds to the uncoordinated carboxylate O3 of INA− from the adjacent framework (O1W···O3 = 2.809(2), 2.900(2), and 2.809(2) Å), resulting in a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure without evident pores (see Figure e).

Crystal Structure of [M(4-OBPT)(INA)(H2O)] (3)

When the reaction temperature was increased to 130 °C in the presence of Co(II), Fe(II), and Zn(II), we found that part 4-OBPT ligands hydrolyzed to INA and the mixed ligands complexes 3a, 3b, and 3c were afforded in situ, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that they are isostructural structures with a monoclinic P21/c space group. As shown in Figure a, each metal ion is coordinated by one hydroxyl oxygen atom (M-O = 2.075(2), 2.010(1), and 2.132(2) Å) and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (M-N = 2.182(3)-2.317(2) Å) from three 4-OBPT ligands, one pyridyl N atom (M-N = 2.165(3), 2.193(2), and 2.168(2) Å) and one carboxyl O atom (M-O = 2.030(2), 1.961(2), and 2.027(2) Å) from two INA- and one water molecule (M-OW =2.167(2), 2.304(2), and 2.181(2) Å) to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry. Each 4-OBPT ligand coordinates to three metal ions acting as a N,N,O-trimonodentate triangular ligand which has a similar coordination model with 4-TPT, but different from those coordination models adopted in complexes 1 and 2. Here, every metal ion coordinates to three 4-OBPT ligands and every ligand connects to three metal ions to yield a (6,3) 2D wavelike layer on the ac plane, as shown in Figure b,c. These are different from the (4,4) nets in complexes 1 and 2 (vide supra). Each INA ligand in situ generated from the hydrolysis of 4-OBPT ligand coordinates to two metal ions via the pyridyl N6, and one of the carboxyl oxygen atoms O2 acts as a pillar that connects the 2D wavelike sheets into a pillared-layer 3D framework (see Figure d). Furthermore, the coordinated water molecule O1W donates an intramolecular hydrogen bond to the N4 (O1W⋅⋅⋅N4 = 2.874(2), 2.794(2), and 2.856(2) Å) from the triazine ring and further hydrogen bonds to the uncoordinated carboxylate O3 of INA- from the adjacent framework (O1W⋅⋅⋅O3 = 2.809(2), 2.900(2), and 2.809(2) Å), resulting in a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure without evident pores (see Figure e).

elements.content: Enlightened by the fact that ligand-directed mediates the supramolecular assembly of 3-TPT and 4-TPT, we extend the insight into the 3-OBPT ligand which has a different geometry from 4-OBPT. When it was used to react with Co(II) ion under the identical condition, complex 4 with a component similar to complex 2 was afforded. It crystallizes in a monoclinic C2/c space group and consists of a Co(II) ion, two 3-OBPT ligands, and two coordinated water molecules as well as a lattice water molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Co(II) ion lies on an inversion center and is coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms (2.148(4) Å) and two oxygen atoms (2.118(3) Å) from the 3-OBPT ligands, and two water molecules (2.129(3) Å) occupying the apical coordination sites to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry. Similar to the ligand 4-OBPT in 2, the 3-OBPT also acts as a N,O-bimonodentate ligand and bridges two metal ions with hydroxyl O atom and one pyridyl N atom. One of the pyridyl N atoms and triazine ring are uncoordinated. However, the structures of 2 and 4 are markedly different due to the different placement of N-atoms between 3-OBPT and 4-OBPT ligands. In complex 4, ligand 3-OBPT prefers to connect two metal ions generating a M2L2 metallamacrocycle with a metal−metal distance of 6.148 Å. The remaining coordination sites of the metal ion are occupied by two water molecules and further completed by two 3-OBPT ligands, extending the metallamacrocycles into a 1D chain via sharing the metal ions along the c axis (see Figure b). The pyridyl and triazine rings within a macrocycle are almost coplanar, and the dihedral angle of the neighboring two macrocycles is 50.9°. Each chain interacts with four adjacent chains via π−π interaction between the pyridyl rings (3.344 Å), resulting in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D channels filled with disordered water molecules as guests (see Figure c). In complex 2, the 4-OBPT also links two metal ions but forms a 2D (4,4) coordination framework.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 4 

Enlightened by the fact that ligand-directed mediates the supramolecular assembly of 3-TPT and 4-TPT, we extend the insight into the 3-OBPT ligand which has a different geometry from 4-OBPT. When it was used to react with Co(II) ion under the identical condition, complex 4 with a component similar to complex 2 was afforded. It crystallizes in a monoclinic C2/c space group and consists of a Co(II) ion, two 3-OBPT ligands, and two coordinated water molecules as well as a lattice water molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Co(II) ion lies on an inversion center and is coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms (2.148(4) Å) and two oxygen atoms (2.118(3) Å) from the 3-OBPT ligands, and two water molecules (2.129(3) Å) occupying the apical coordination sites to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry. Similar to the ligand 4-OBPT in 2, the 3-OBPT also acts as a N,O-bimonodentate ligand and bridges two metal ions with hydroxyl O atom and one pyridyl N atom. One of the pyridyl N atoms and triazine ring are uncoordinated. However, the structures of 2 and 4 are markedly different due to the different placement of N-atoms between 3-OBPT and 4-OBPT ligands. In complex 4, ligand 3-OBPT prefers to connect two metal ions generating a M2L2 metallamacrocycle with a metal-metal distance of 6.148 Å. The remaining coordination sites of the metal ion are occupied by two water molecules and further completed by two 3-OBPT ligands, extending the metallamacrocycles into a 1D chain via sharing the metal ions along the c axis (see Figure b). The pyridyl and triazine rings within a macrocycle are almost coplanar, and the dihedral angle of the neighboring two macrocycles is 50.9°. Each chain interacts with four adjacent chains via π-π interaction between the pyridyl rings (3.344 Å), resulting in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D channels filled with disordered water molecules as guests (see Figure c). In complex 2, the 4-OBPT also links two metal ions but forms a 2D (4,4) coordination framework.

elements.content: The complexes are isostructural and crystallize in monoclinic P21/n space group. Similar to complex 3, part 3-OBPT ligand hydrolyzed to NA and the mixed ligands complexes 5a and 5b were obtained in situ when the reaction temperature was increased to 130 °C in the presence of Co(II) and Ni(II) ions, respectively. Each complex consists of a metal ion, a 3-OBPT ligand, a NA− ion, and a coordinated water molecule as well as half of a methanol molecule in an asymmetrical unit. As shown in Figure a, each metal ion coordinates to N1, N5, and O1 from three 3-OBPT ligands, respectively, N6, O2 from two NA− ions and a water molecule O1W to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry. Each 3-OBPT ligand coordinates to three metal ions acting as a N,N,O-trimonodentate triangular ligand which has a similar coordination model with 4-OBPT in complex 3, but different from those adopted in complexes 1, 2, and 4. Four pyridyl groups from two 3-OBPT ligands linking two metal ions generate a dinuclear macrocycle with metal−metal distances of 7.079 Å for 5a or 7.018 Å for 5b, which is further stabilized by two NA bridges. The remaining coordination sites of the metal ions are further coordinated by two water molecules and completed by two hydroxyl groups from the neighboring dinuclear macrocycles, resulting in a 2D coordination sheet (see Figure b). Here the dinuclear macrocycle can be envisaged as a four-connected node, leading to a (4,4) net (see Figure c). This is markedly different from complex 3 (vide supra). Within the 2D sheet, hydrogen bonds between the coordinated water molecule O1W and the uncoordinated O3 of carboxylate (O1W···O3 = 2.703 Å (5a) and 2.706 Å (5b)) were observed. Furthermore, the hydrogen-bonded interactions between the coordinated water molecule O1W and N2 of triazine (O1W···N2 = 2.971 Å (5a) and 2.984 Å (5b)) assemble the 2D layers into a 3D network with one-dimensional (1D) channels filled with the disordered methanol solvents (see Figure d).

elements.content: The ligand 4-HOBPT or 3-HOBPT was prepared by the reaction of 4-cyanopyridine or 3-cyanopyridine and urea in the presence of sodium hydride as a catalyst according to the similar synthetic procedure of 2-HOBPT. They slightly dissolve in methanol and ethanol, but dissolve in DMF and DMSO. To observe the coordination behavior of the ligands, reactions of 4-HOBPT or 3-HOBPT ligand with different metal ions under various temperatures were examined. The summary is brief outlined in Scheme . First, the reactions of 4-HOBPT with Co(II) under hydrothermal conditions in the range of 90−130 °C were carried out. Unique complex 1a was obtained in high yield (ca 90%) under 120 °C, in which the ligand is a tridentate, adopting an unusual N,O-exo-bidentate chelating and N-monodentate mode (see Scheme ). However, one of pyridyl groups is free though it is a good coordinate group. This prompted us to examine the reaction at high temperature. When the temperature increased to 130 °C, mixed complexes 1a (yellow) and 3a (purple) were obtained and collected by manual separation under a microscope. Their phase purities were confirmed by comparison of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized products with the simulated ones from the single-crystal data (see the ). In complex 3a, part ligands hydrolyze to INA and the 4-OBPT ligand acts as a trimonodentate triangular ligand like 4-TPT. To examine the thermal stability of the 4-OBPT ligand, the reaction temperature was further increased to 140 °C; however, only powder was obtained. IR spectra show the 4-OBPT ligand hydrolyzes completely to INA. The above experiments seem to show that the ligand is unstable at 130 °C in the presence of Co(II) ion and favor adopting a N,N,O-trimonodentate at high temperature (see Scheme ). Second, to observe the effect of metal ions on the ligand stability and coordination model, various ions such as Ni(II), Fe(II), Zn(II), and Cu(II) were also employed to react with the ligand under the identical conditions. The same case was observed in the presence of Ni(II) ion. When Fe(II) ion was used, similar cases were observed. At 130 °C, mixed complexes 2 (red, 50%) and 3b (black, 18%) were afforded, where the ligand is N,O-bimonodentate and the triazine nitrogen is uncoordination in 2. A significant difference was found in the case of Zn(II); complex 3c is the main product (yield 48%) at 130 °C, though complexes 3a and 3b are the byproducts in the corresponding reactions, indicating that Zn(II) ion facilitates the ligand hydrolysis. This also encouraged us to observe the reaction in the presence of Cu(II) ion because the fact that Cu(II) and Rh(III) ions promote the hydrolysis of 2-TPT has been reported. This is indeed the case. We found that the ligand 4-OBPT hydrolyzed to INA at 100 °C in the presence of Cu(II) ion and the unique product Cu(INA)2(H2O)4 was isolated. This may be attributed to the decrease in electron density at the carbon atoms of the triazine ring by the electron-withdrawing effect of the metal ion and the increase in nucleophilic attack to the carbon atoms of triazine ring. Third, when the 3-OBPT ligand was used instead of 4-OBPT similar cases were observed and summarized in Scheme .

Syntheses and Hydrolysis Reaction

The ligand 4-HOBPT or 3-HOBPT was prepared by the reaction of 4-cyanopyridine or 3-cyanopyridine and urea in the presence of sodium hydride as a catalyst according to the similar synthetic procedure of 2-HOBPT. They slightly dissolve in methanol and ethanol, but dissolve in DMF and DMSO. To observe the coordination behavior of the ligands, reactions of 4-HOBPT or 3-HOBPT ligand with different metal ions under various temperatures were examined. The summary is brief outlined in Scheme . First, the reactions of 4-HOBPT with Co(II) under hydrothermal conditions in the range of 90-130 °C were carried out. Unique complex 1a was obtained in high yield (ca 90%) under 120 °C, in which the ligand is a tridentate, adopting an unusual N,O-exo-bidentate chelating and N-monodentate mode (see Scheme ). However, one of pyridyl groups is free though it is a good coordinate group. This prompted us to examine the reaction at high temperature. When the temperature increased to 130 °C, mixed complexes 1a (yellow) and 3a (purple) were obtained and collected by manual separation under a microscope. Their phase purities were confirmed by comparison of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized products with the simulated ones from the single-crystal data (see the ). In complex 3a, part ligands hydrolyze to INA and the 4-OBPT ligand acts as a trimonodentate triangular ligand like 4-TPT. To examine the thermal stability of the 4-OBPT ligand, the reaction temperature was further increased to 140 °C; however, only powder was obtained. IR spectra show the 4-OBPT ligand hydrolyzes completely to INA. The above experiments seem to show that the ligand is unstable at 130 °C in the presence of Co(II) ion and favor adopting a N,N,O-trimonodentate at high temperature (see Scheme ). Second, to observe the effect of metal ions on the ligand stability and coordination model, various ions such as Ni(II), Fe(II), Zn(II), and Cu(II) were also employed to react with the ligand under the identical conditions. The same case was observed in the presence of Ni(II) ion. When Fe(II) ion was used, similar cases were observed. At 130 °C, mixed complexes 2 (red, 50%) and 3b (black, 18%) were afforded, where the ligand is N,O-bimonodentate and the triazine nitrogen is uncoordination in 2. A significant difference was found in the case of Zn(II); complex 3c is the main product (yield 48%) at 130 °C, though complexes 3a and 3b are the byproducts in the corresponding reactions, indicating that Zn(II) ion facilitates the ligand hydrolysis. This also encouraged us to observe the reaction in the presence of Cu(II) ion because the fact that Cu(II) and Rh(III) ions promote the hydrolysis of 2-TPT has been reported. This is indeed the case. We found that the ligand 4-OBPT hydrolyzed to INA at 100 °C in the presence of Cu(II) ion and the unique product Cu(INA)2(H2O)4 was isolated. This may be attributed to the decrease in electron density at the carbon atoms of the triazine ring by the electron-withdrawing effect of the metal ion and the increase in nucleophilic attack to the carbon atoms of triazine ring. Third, when the 3-OBPT ligand was used instead of 4-OBPT similar cases were observed and summarized in Scheme .

elements.content: Ligands 4-HOBPT and 3-HOBPT are potential polydentate, generally in N,N- and N,O-bidentate, and N,N,O-tridentate. Structural analyses exhibit that both ligands prefer the N,N,O-trimonodentate model rather than the bimonodentate model at high reaction temperature (see Scheme ), in which the ligands can be regarded as 3-connected triangular ligands like TPT. Because of the different placement of the N-atom in the pyridyl group both 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT have different geometries and exhibit diverse assembly. In the 4-OBPT ligand, the coordination sites locate at the vertexes of the triangular pane; it prefers to connect three metal ions in three directions generating a (6,3) 2D sheet. However, in the 3-OBPT ligand the coordination nitrogen atoms position on the edges of the triangular pane; it forms a M2L2 metallamacrocycle and then further donates the hydroxyl oxygen to the metal ions from other metallamacrocycles resulting in a (4,4) 2D net.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Models and Ligand-directed Assembly

Ligands 4-HOBPT and 3-HOBPT are potential polydentate, generally in N,N- and N,O-bidentate, and N,N,O-tridentate. Structural analyses exhibit that both ligands prefer the N,N,O-trimonodentate model rather than the bimonodentate model at high reaction temperature (see Scheme ), in which the ligands can be regarded as 3-connected triangular ligands like TPT. Because of the different placement of the N-atom in the pyridyl group both 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT have different geometries and exhibit diverse assembly. In the 4-OBPT ligand, the coordination sites locate at the vertexes of the triangular pane; it prefers to connect three metal ions in three directions generating a (6,3) 2D sheet. However, in the 3-OBPT ligand the coordination nitrogen atoms position on the edges of the triangular pane; it forms a M2L2 metallamacrocycle and then further donates the hydroxyl oxygen to the metal ions from other metallamacrocycles resulting in a (4,4) 2D net.

elements.content: On the other hand, both 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands adopt a N,O-bimonodentate model to meet the charge balance at the relatively low reaction temperature. In 4-OBPT ligand, the coordination sites sit at the two vertexes of the triangular pane generating a (4,4) 2D sheet. However, 3-OBPT ligand prefers to bind two metal ions forming a dinuclear macrocycle, then generates a 1D chain via sharing the metal ions due to the coordination nitrogen on the edge of the triangular pane. The great diversity in coordination sites of the ligands induces various self-assembly.

However, 3-OBPT ligand prefers to bind two metal ions forming a dinuclear macrocycle, then generates a 1D chain via sharing the metal ions due to the coordination nitrogen on the edge of the triangular pane. elements.content: We have demonstrated that the thermal stability and coordination fashion of 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands are extremely dependent on the reaction temperature and the presence of metal ions under hydrothermal conditions. In the range of 90−120 °C, both ligands adopt a N,O-bimonodentate coordination model, whereas they are a N,N,O-trimonodentate triangular ligand at 130 °C concomitant with part ligands hydrolysis. The promoted hydrolysis reaction of the ligands by Cu(II) ion was also proven even at the relative low temperature. The great diversity of coordination sites between 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands leads to various supramolecular architectures, exhibiting ligand-directed supramolecular assembly.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have demonstrated that the thermal stability and coordination fashion of 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands are extremely dependent on the reaction temperature and the presence of metal ions under hydrothermal conditions. In the range of 90-120 °C, both ligands adopt a N,O-bimonodentate coordination model, whereas they are a N,N,O-trimonodentate triangular ligand at 130 °C concomitant with part ligands hydrolysis. The promoted hydrolysis reaction of the ligands by Cu(II) ion was also proven even at the relative low temperature. The great diversity of coordination sites between 4-OBPT and 3-OBPT ligands leads to various supramolecular architectures, exhibiting ligand-directed supramolecular assembly.

FT IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (m), 3285 (s), 2927 (w), 1628 (vs), 1568 (vs), 1526 (vs), 1475 (s), 1382 (vs), 1238 (w), 1149 (w), 1052 (m), 1014 (m), 943 (w), 862 (w), 827 (s), 772 (s), 695 (s), 557 (w), 505 (w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of 4-HOBPT and 3-HOBPT

They were prepared according to previously reported procedures, using of 4-cyanopyridine or 3-cyanopyridine instead of 2-cyanopyridine as the starting material. For 4-HOBPT: Yield 72% based on urea. ESI-MS: m/z = 250 [M - H]-. 1H NMR data (DMSO-d 6, ppm): 8.815 (d, J = 1.84 Hz, 4H), 8.27 (d, J = 1.80 Hz, 4H). For 3-HOBPT: Yield 60% based on urea. ESI-MS: m/z = 250 [M - H]-. 1H NMR data (DMSO-d 6, ppm): 9.50 (s, 2H), 8.77 (d, J = 4.75 Hz, 2H), 8.69 (d, J = 7.95 Hz, 2H), 7.58(t, 2H).

Syntheses of [Co(4-OBPT)2]⋅0.6H2O (1a) and Co(4-OBPT)(INA)(H2O) (3a)

4-HOBPT (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol), 7 mL of distilled water, and 7 mL of methanol were put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr vessel. The mixture was heated at 90-130 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. The resulting mixture was filtered. The crystals were washed by water, dried at room temperature, and collected by manual separation under a microscope. At 90-120 °C, unique yellow 1a was obtained in about 90% yield on the basis of 4-HOBPT. When the temperature was increased to 130 °C, mixed complexes 1a and 3a were obtained. Yield of 3a: 12% based on 4-HOBPT. Anal. Calcd for C19H14CoN6O4 (3a): C, 50.79, H, 3.14, N, 18.71%. Found: C, 50.87, H, 3.32, N, 18.54%. FT IR (KBr, cm-1): 3553 (m), 3435 (s), 3246 (m), 3115 (w), 1630 (vs), 1572 (vs), 1524 (s), 1468 (s), 1373 (vs), 1223 (m), 1144 (w), 1061 (m), 1014 (m), 824 (m), 771 (m), 698 (m), 552 (w), 507 (m).

Syntheses of [Fe(4-OBPT)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O (2) and Fe(4-OBPT)(INA)(H2O) (3b)

4-HOBPT (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol), FeCl2⋅6H2O (0.118 g, 0.5 mmol), 7 mL of distilled water, and 7 mL of methanol were put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr vessel. The mixture was heated at 100-130 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and the resulting mixture was filtered. The crystals were dried at room temperature and collected by manual separation under a microscope. At 100 °C, only red 2 was obtained in 60% based on 4-HOBPT. Anal. Calcd for C26H32FeN10O10 (2): C, 44.58, H, 4.60, N, 19.99%. Found: C, 45.22, H, 4.32, N, 20.44%. FT IR (KBr, cm-1): 3404 (s), 3242 (w), 1641 (m), 1580 (m), 1518 (vs), 1481 (vs), 1373 (s), 1315 (w), 1271 (w), 1217 (w), 1188 (w), 1142 (w), 1061 (m), 1011 (m), 854 (w), 820 (s), 758 (w), 698 (m), 650 (m), 505 (m). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment of 2 was carried out from 30 to 750 °C. The weight loss of 20.2% in the range of 20-200 °C (see Figure S6 in the ) corresponds to the loss of eight water molecules (six lattice and two coordinated water molecules, calculated 20.5%). When the temperature was set to 130 °C, two compounds 2 (red, 50%) and 3b (black, 18%) were obtained. Anal. Calcd for C19H14FeN6O4 (3b): C, 51.14, H, 3.16, N, 18.83%; Found: C, 51.02, H, 3.42, N, 18.27%. FT IR (KBr, cm-1): 3448 (s), 2926 (w), 1630 (vs), 1582 (vs), 1523 (s), 1475 (vs), 1375 (vs), 1221 (m), 1142 (w), 1061 (m), 1016 (m), 947 (w), 862(w), 822 (s), 765 (m), 698 (s), 507 (w).

Synthesis of Zn(4-OBPT)(INA)(H2O) (3c)

The reaction was carried out using a method similar to that for 3a, using ZnSO4 instead of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O; the temperature was set to 130 °C. The resulting mixture was filtered. The filtration residue was washed by water and ethanol and collected by manual separation under a microscope. The colorless crystals 3c were obtained in 48% base on 4-HOBPT. Anal. Calcd for C19H14ZnN6O4 (3c): C, 50.07, H, 3.10, N, 18.44%; Found: C, 49.68, H, 3.34, N, 18.39%. FT IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445 (s), 3248 (w), 3061 (w), 2926 (w), 1624 (vs), 1582 (vs), 1524 (vs), 1468 (vs), 1375 (vs), 1223 (m), 1142 (w), 1061 (m), 1016 (m), 945 (w), 862 (w), 822 (s), 775 (m), 698 (s), 553 (w), 507 (w).

Syntheses of [Co(3-OBPT)2(H2O)2]⋅H2O (4) and [Co(3-OBPT)(NA)(H2O)]⋅0.5CH3OH (5a)

3-HOBPT (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol), 7 mL of distilled water, and 7 mL of methanol were put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr vessel. The mixture was heated at 110-130 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. The resulting mixture was filtered. The crystals were washed by water, dried at room temperature, and collected by manual separation under a microscope. At 110 °C, only light red noodle-like 4 was obtained in about 55% yield based on 3-HOBPT. Anal. Calcd for C26H22CoN10O5 (4): C, 50.90, H, 3.61, N, 22.83%; Found: C, 50.67, H, 3.82, N, 22.58%. FT IR (KBr, cm-1): 3391 (s), 2928 (w), 1541 (vs), 1481 (vs), 1420 (s), 1375 (s), 1198 (m), 1103 (w), 1016 (m), 954 (w), 860(m), 818 (s), 702 (s), 652 (w), 505 (w). When the temperature was up to 130 °C, dark red block 5a was obtained in about 25% yield. Anal. Calcd for C19.50H16CoN6O4.50 (5a): C, 50.33, H, 3.46, N, 18.06%; Found: C, 50.41, H, 3.62, N, 17.84%. FT IR (KBr, cm-1): 3265 (s), 3062 (w), 2926 (w), 1624 (vs), 1578 (s), 1526 (vs), 1472 (s), 1382 (vs), 1241 (w), 1198 (w), 1151 (w), 1047 (m), 1013 (m), 862 (w), 825 (s), 768 (s), 694 (s), 603 (m), 554 (w), 508 (w).

Synthesis of [Ni(3-OBPT)(NA)(H2O)]⋅0.5CH3OH (5b)

The reaction was carried out using a method similar to that for 5a, using Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O instead of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O; the temperature was at 130 °C. The resulting mixture was filtered. The filtration residue was washed by water and methanol, then collected by manual separation under a microscope. Dark green block crystals were obtained in 18% yield. Anal. Calcd for C19.50H16NiN6O4.50 (5b): C, 50.36, H, 3.47, N, 18.07%; Found: C, 50.38, H, 3.75, N, 17.91%.
